awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Captivology-Stimuli-based Learning (CAPITAL) of Big Data Security (BigSec): Towards a Science/Engineering, Career-Oriented Training
awd_abstract_narration:
Big data applications are widely utilized today in a variety of scientific and social studies. The International Data Corporation (IDC) reports that more than 50% of all big data business revenues originate in the United States. Big data requires "bigger responsibility" in terms of protecting the storage, sharing, and access of the privacy-sensitive data. In today's higher education, there are limited big data security (BigSec) educational activities that target comprehensive and profound understanding of BigSec attack models, as well as defense solutions, at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Some available BigSec training materials are mostly online, used for short-term training, and only cover general concepts from a business management viewpoint. The nation is currently experiencing a shortage of cybersecurity professionals, including the experts in big data security. The goal of this project from the University of Alabama Tuscaloosa is to utilize new pedagogy, called Captivology-Stimuli-based Learning (CAPITAL), for active education and training on big data security and privacy.

This project will make two significant contributions to enhance BigSec education. The first is the development of a new series of BigSec course materials, including an undergraduate course, CECS 400/500 Big Data Security, which targets fundamental knowledge of big data security issues, as well as a graduate course, CECS 600 Advanced Topics on Big Data Security and Privacy, which aims to enhance the cybersecurity research skills of graduate students. The second is the implementation of CAPITAL pedagogy in BigSec education. This includes implementation of the flipped classroom model, Virtual Reality based security games, Capstone design showcase, student cybersecurity design competitions, and patent-targeted thesis projects. This project will conduct the pioneering "active" education to train a BigSec-literate workforce. All the BigSec created education materials will be disseminated to other schools.

por.por_cntn:
Big data requires bigger responsibility: the larger the concentration of sensitive personal data, the more attractive a database is to criminals. A single successful big data security breach comprising millions of records can cause multimillion-dollar losses and other serious consequences for the victimized organization. In this project, we have developed educational materials for both undergraduate and graduate students on big data security.

Intellectual Merit: The following outcomes are produced from this development:

(1) We have developed two complete, semester-long BigSec courses: An undergraduate course, CECS 400/500 Big Data Security, was developed and offered to undergraduate students in ECE and CS majors at UA/UAB.  The other course, CECS 600 Advanced Topics on Big Data Security and Privacy, was also developed and offered to our over graduate students in ECE/CS. It focuses on the research skill enhancement and creative solutions.

(2) We have used new pedagogy that includes flipped classroom and VR-based active learning, and other teaching methods such as capstone design showcase, student project competitions, and patent-targeted graduate research projects. 

(3) We have performed career-oriented training. We have trained the students (especially graduate students) based on their individual career goals. For example, if a student targets faculty positions, the research and writing skills will be emphasized. We have also aopted engineering/science differentiated education: CS students are assigned more programming tasks, while ECE students prefer hardware-based labs.

(4) We have encouraged innovative big data security solution seeking by using multiple approaches such as class projects, term papers, research presentations.  We have improved the graduate students’ research skills in BigSec (big data security) domain. Instead of teaching the solutions to each BigSec problem, we have used flipped classroom, term papers, and class labs, to encourage the students to read the papers and seek innovative solution. We have focused on the attacks/solutions in 3 popular big data types: big graph, big table, and big flow: There are many interesting security issues in those 3 formats, such as big graph query attack, big table storage attack, big flow transmission attack, etc. The 15-week lectures/labs explain how to identify, model, and overcome the various attacks specific to big graph/table/flow. Students are trained to seek the security schemes that are scalable, have low overhead/complexity, and use distributed/parallel implementations: Students are always encouraged to find security solutions that are suitable to large-scale data processing.

Evaluation: Our learning assessment expert has helped us to evaluate students' outcomes and found that our teaching materials have helped students to improve the understanding of advanced cyber security topics. For undergraduate course, we have focused on the evaluation of solid foundation of the basic big data lifecycle attacks and countermeasures. We paid attention to the appropriate depth / scope for BigSec algorithms and protocols. While for graduate course, we mainly evaluated how much the students’ research skills had been enhanced. For example, did students learn how to think outside the box for a new big data attack that has never been defined before? Can they come up with innovative solutions that meet the scalability and low-overhead requirements of big data applications? Did the term paper assignment improve their academic writing skills? How many graduate students finally chose BigSec as their thesis/dissertation topics? etc. Multiple BS students eventually decided to pursue graduate studies in cybersecurity.

Broader Impacts:

(1) Impacts on UA BigSec education: Due to our complete cybersecurity curriculum and fruitful research outcomes, the National Security Agency and DHS have designated UA as a National Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) in Cyber Defense Research. This BigSec education has significantly stimulated the development of UA CAE to train stronger national cybersecurity professionals.

(2) Impacts on national cybersecurity workforce: The International Data Corporation (IDC) reports that more than 50% of all big data business revenues originate in the U.S., and U.S. market alone will reach more than $98 billion by 2019. In 2016 alone the 3 large companies in the U.S. (IBM, Cisco, ORACLE) advertised over 26, 488 big data related positions. This project has conducted the pioneering ‘active’ education to train BigSec workforce. All of our developed materials are freely posted and distributed to other schools. It has big impacts on the national big data security/privacy training.
